titleStmt.title: Chronicle of Edessa
SPEAR: Syriac Persons, Events, and Relations
titleStmt.funder: The National Endowment for the Humanities

category.catDesc: Used to denote a date calculated by the editor from a regnal year given in the text.

event.desc:
In
November A. D. 201
Teshri II A. Gr. 513
during the reign of
Abgar the Great ,
the Daisan river
flooded
Edessa
destroying the western wall of the city,
the Great Palace , and
the Church of the Christians .

personGrp.persName:
Workers in the
government of
Edessa
in
November A. D. 201
Teshri II A. Gr. 513

state.desc:
The workers
were
government officials
in
Edessa .

personGrp.persName:
The wise men of
Edessa
in
November A. D. 201
Teshri II A. Gr. 513

event.desc:
In
November A. D. 201
Teshri II A. Gr. 513
,
Abgar
commanded the removal of the flood gates of
Edessa .

personGrp.persName:
The two thousand people killed by flooding in
Edessa
in
November A. D. 201
Teshri II A. Gr. 513
.

event.desc:
Two thousand people
were killed in
Edessa
by the
flooding of
the Daisan river
in
November A. D. 201
Teshri II A. Gr. 513
.

The craftsmen of
Edessa
in

Teshri II A. Gr. 513
.

state.desc:

artisans
in
Edessa .

event.desc:
In
November A. D. 201
Teshri II A. Gr. 513
,
Abgar
commanded the
craftsmen of
Edessa
to remove their cottage from the banks of the
Daisan river .

personGrp.persName:
The measurers and men of skill of
Edessa
in

Teshri II A. Gr. 513
.

state.desc:

in
Edessa .

personGrp.persName:
Those who lived in the portico in
Edessa
in
November A. D. 201
Teshri II A. Gr. 513

The islanders of
Edessa
in
November A. D. 201
Teshri II A. Gr. 513
.

state.desc:
The islanders
were the
watchmen
of the city of
Edessa .

event.desc:
In
November A. D. 201
Teshri II A. Gr. 513
,
Abgar
commanded
those who live in the portico of
Edessa
not to lodge in their cottages during the winter.

After
November A. D. 201
Teshri II A. Gr. 513
,
Abgar
commanded to be built
a royal house in
Beth Tabara
where he dwelt during the winters.

personGrp.persName:
The nobles of
Abgar
of
Edessa
in
November A. D. 201
Teshri II A. Gr. 513
.

state.desc:
These men were the
nobles
of
Abgar
of
Edessa .

event.desc:
After
November A. D. 201
Teshri II A. Gr. 513
,
Abgar
remitted the taxes of
Edessa
and the surrounding towns for five years on account of the flood.

,

two synkelli
survived
an earthquake that
destroyed
Nicopolis
.

In
January A. D. 499
Kānun II A. Gr. 810
a sign like a spear appeared for many days in the sky above
Edessa .

In
A. D. 498/9
A. Gr. 810
Anastasios
deposed
Euphemius .

In
A. D. 498/9
A. Gr. 810
Macedon
became
Bishop
of
Constantinople
after the
deposition of
Euphemius
.

In
A. D. 499/500
A. Gr. 811
locusts devoured the grain of
Edessa .

On
22 August A. D. 502
22 Āb A. Gr. 813
a great fire appeared in the north of the city of
Edessa .

Kavad
besieged the city of
Amida
from 5 November A. D. 502 to 10 February A. D. 503
for 97 days beginning on 5 Teshri II A. Gr. 814

On
10 February A. D. 503
the 97th day after 5 Teshri II A. Gr. 814
Kavad
captured the city of
Amida .

In
September A. D. 503
Elul A. Gr. 814
Kavad
besieged
Edessa
but did not capture it.

During
the seige of
Edessa
in
September A. D. 503
Elul A. Gr. 814
Kavad
burned the House of
Mar Sergius
and
the House of the Confessors .

orig.date: The Sabbath of the Resurrection A. Gr. 821

person.note: Peter died on 10 April A. D. 510.

event.desc:
On
10 April A. D. 510
the Sabbath of the Resurrection A. Gr. 821
Peter
died.

After
10 April A. D. 510
the Sabbath of the Resurrection A. Gr. 821
Pawlā
became
Bishop
of
Edessa .

In
A. D. 511/2 This date was calculated from a regnal year.
the 21st year of the reign of Anastasios
Anastasios
commanded them to open the coffin of
Euphemia the martyr , remove the book placed there by the
Council of
Chalcedon
, and burn it.
Anastasios
relented when fire from heaven struck the faces of
those wishing to remove it .

personGrp.persName:
Those struck by fire in
A. D. 511/2 This date was calculated from a regnal year.
the 21st year of the reign of Anastasios
because they wanted to remove the book placed in the coffin of
Euphemia the martyr
by the
Council of
Chalcedon
.

event.desc:
In
A. D. 511/2 This date was calculated from a regnal year.
the 21st year of the reign of Anastasios
Anastasios
deposed
Macedon
because he did not anathematize the
Council of
Chalcedon
.

In
A. D. 511/2 This date was calculated from a regnal year.
the 21st year of the reign of Anastasios
Timotheos
became
Bishop
of
Constantinople .

In
A. D. 511/2 This date was calculated from a regnal year.
the 24st year of the reign of Anastasios
Vitalian
rebelled against
Anastasios .

person.note: Anastasios died on 9 July A. D. 518.

event.desc:
On
9 July A. D. 518
9 Tammuz A. Gr. 829
Anastasios
died.

After
9 July A. D. 518
9 Tammuz A. Gr. 829
Justin
became
King
of
Rome .

In
A. D. 499/500
A. Gr. 830
Justin
deposed
Severus
and
Philoxenos
for refusing to accept the
Council of
Chalcedon
.

On
4 November A. D. 519
4 Teshri II A. Gr. 831
Patricius
arrived in
Edessa
at the command of
the Emperor Justin
in order to urge
Bishop
Pawlā
to receive the
Council of
Chalcedon
or else be deposed.

After
4 November A. D. 519
4 Teshri II A. Gr. 831
,
Bishop
Pawlā
refused to accept the
Council of
Chalcedon
. When
Patricius
threatened to remove him from
Edessa
he fled to the
House of Baptism . Fearing the command of
Emperor Justin ,
Patricius
removed
Bishop
Pawlā
to
Seleucia .

In
A. D. 520/1
A. Gr. 832
, the
Emperor Justin
returned
Bishop
Pawlā
to his episcopal see in
Edessa
hoping that he would accept the
Council of
Chalcedon
.

Pawlā
refused to accept the
Council of
Chalcedon
and on
27 July 27 A. D. 522
27 Tammuz A. Gr. 833
Emperor Justin
deposed him and exiled him to
Euchata .

Asclepius
became
bishop
and entered the city of
Edessa
on
23 October A. D. 522
23 Teshri I A. Gr. 834
.

personGrp.persName:
The monks of the east in
24 December A. D. 522
24 Kānun I A. Gr. 834

state.desc:
The monks of the east
were
monks .

event.desc:
In
24 December A. D. 522
24 Kānun I A. Gr. 834
Bishop
Asclepius
drove off
the monks of the east
because they would not accept the
Council of
Chalcedon
.

In
A. D. 524/5
A. Gr. 836
a flood destroyed
Edessa
for the fourth time.

person.note: Asclepius died on 27 June A. D. 525.

event.desc:
In
A. D. 424/5
A. Gr. 836
, after
the flooding of
Edessa
Asclepius
fled
Edessa
and spent 70 days in
Antioch
with
Euphrasius .

Asclepius
died in
Antioch
on
27 June A. D. 525
27 Ḥazirān A. Gr. 836
.

On
4 September A. D. 525
4 Elul A. Gr. 836
they moved the body of
Asclepius
from
Antioch
to
Edessa
where he was buried alongside
Nonos
in the
the House of
Mar Barlāhā
.

After
27 June A. D. 525
27 Ḥazirān A. Gr. 836
,
Pawlā
repented of his opposition to the
Council of
Chalcedon
, petitioned
Justinian
for the return of his episcopal see, and wrote a libellus affirming the
council
to
Euphrasius the
Patriarch
.

Following
Pawlā's
acceptance of the
Council of
Chalcedon
and a letter of support from
Justinian ,
the Emperor Justin
restored
Pawlā
to his episcopal see and he entered
Edessa
on
8 March A. D. 526
8 Ādar A. Gr. 837
.

person.note: Pawlā died on 30 October A. D. 526.

event.desc:
On
30 October A. D. 526
30 Teshri I A. Gr. 838
Pawlā
died.

Andreos
became
bishop
and entered the city of
Edessa
on
7 February A. D. 527
7 Shebāṭ A. Gr. 838
.

Justinian
put into the diptychs of the church the four holy synods:
the Council of
Nicaea
,
the Council of
Constantinople
,
the Council of
Ephesus
, and
the Council of
Chalcedon
.

On
5 October A. D. 538
5 Teshri I A. Gr. 850
a sign like a spear appeared in the sky above
Edessa .

On
29 May A. D. 526
29 Iyār A. Gr. 837
at the seventh hour a great earthquake struck
Antioch .

On
15 November A. D. 527
15 Teshri II A. Gr. 839
a great fire of unknown origin burned much of what remained of
Antioch
after it was
destroyed by earthquake .

person.note: Euphrasius died on 29 May A. D. 526.

event.desc:
On
29 May A. D. 526
29 Iyār A. Gr. 837
Euphrasius the
Patriarch
of
Antioch
died in an
earthquake .

state.desc:
Ephrem of
Amida
was
Comes
of
the East .

Ephrem of
Amida
was
Patriarch
of
Antioch .

event.desc:
After
29 May A. D. 526
29 Iyār A. Gr. 8371
Ephrem of
Amida
became
Patriarch
of
Antioch .

person.note: Andreos died in December, A. D. 532.

event.desc:
In
December A. D. 532
Kānun I A. Gr. 844
Andreos
died and was buried in the
the House of
Mar Barlāhā
alongside the bones of
Mar Nonos
and
Mar Asclepius

Addai
became
bishop
and entered the city of
Edessa
on
28 August A. D. 533
28 Āb A. Gr. 844
.

On
1 April A. D. 527
1 Nisān A. Gr. 838
Justinian
became
Caesar .

On
10 August A. D. 527
10 Āb A. Gr. 838
Justinian
became the sole
King
of
Rome .

person.note: Justin died on 10 August A. D. 527.

event.desc:
On
10 August A. D. 527
10 Āb A. Gr. 838
Justin
died.

personGrp.persName:
The Roman army commanded by
Demosthenes
in
July A. D. 531
Tammuz A. Gr. 842

event.desc:
In
July A. D. 531
Tammuz A. Gr. 842
Demosthenes
arrived in
Edessa
to command
the Roman army .

personGrp.persName:
The Huns
who entered
Roman territory
on
18 December A. D. 531
18 Kānun I A. Gr. 843

event.desc:
On
18 December A. D. 531
18 Kānun I A. Gr. 843
the Huns
entered
Roman territory
and plundered as far as the area around
Aleppo
and
Antioch .

person.note: Demosthenes died on 10 January A. D. 532.

event.desc:
On
10 January A. D. 532
10 Kānun II A. Gr. 843
Demosthenes
fell sick and died in
Tella
while
fighting the
the Huns
.

In
September A. D. 532
Elul A. Gr. 843
Rufinus
made peace between
Rome , and
Persia .

There was
peace
between
Rome
and
Persia
from
September A. D. 532 to May A. D. 540
Elul A. Gr. 843 to Iyār A. Gr. 851

person.persName:
Chosroes the
King
of
the Persians

event.desc:
In
May A. D. 540
Iyār A. Gr. 851
Chosroes
broke the
peace
and invaded
Roman territory . He laid waste
Shura ,
Aleppo , and
Antioch .

personGrp.persName:
The great men of the city of
Edessa
in
May A. D. 540
Iyār A. Gr. 851

event.desc:
After
May A. D. 540
Iyār A. Gr. 851
,
the great men of the city of
Edessa
saved the city from
Chosroes
by paying him two centenaria of gold, after which
Chosroes
returned to
Persia .

The first time the walls of
Edessa
were broken down
was in
November A. D. 201
Teshri II A. Gr. 513

The second time the walls of
Edessa
were broken down . was in the days of
Diocletian the
King
in
May A. D. 303
Iyār A. Gr. 614

The third time the walls of
Edessa
were broken down
was in the days of the
Kings
Honorios
and
Theodosius
and of the
bishop
Rabbula
in
March A. D. 413
Ādar A. Gr. 724
.

The fourth time the walls of
Edessa
were broken down
was in the days of the
king
Justin
and of the
bishop
Asclepius
in
A. D. 424/5
A. Gr. 836

bibl.title: Stewards of the Poor: The Man of God, Rabbula, and Hiba in Fifth-Century Edessa
